abstract.text: No overview available.
Query the current view’s or guide’s subviews for all padder views
that have contained views of a specific type.
e.g. view.query.padders(of:Button.self)
Given a factory with multiple base items, lift this into
separate factories that union their query results.
Use this in case of multiple base items where you need
to perform a query with maximum matches (e.g. first of)
so that it does that for each base item hierarchy.
Query the current view’s subviews for all Steppers
Query the current layer for it’s parent layer.
In the case of multiple base items, this will
return the common parent. NOTE: the return type
is upcast to the most general type: CALayer.
BEWARE: this ignores parent guides. See also,
“parent” operator which respects parent guides.
Query for a Quadrant with a string identifier
Query the current guide for it’s root guide.
In the case of multiple base items, this will
return the common root or none if there is no
common root. NOTE: the return type is upcast
to the most general type: Guide
Query the current item for all sub-items using a string identifier.
Set identifiers on any view/layer e.g. view.identifier = “com.dj.go”.
This method returns
items with that identifier (i.e. not just
the first). Whether ids are treated as unique is up to the implementor.
See Identifiable.swift
Caveat: a string id doesn’t necessarily map to an IdentifiableItem
enum label (where that has been used), since those have a prefix.
e.g. “login” != “com.identifiers.blahblah.login”
Query the current view for it’s parent view.
In the case of multiple base items, this will
return the common parent. NOTE: the return type
is upcast to the most general type: UIView.
If the parent is a guide then this will return
an empty query. To get the parent guide call
.parent(Guide.self). To get the actual super
view, use “literalParent”.
Query the current node for it’s root node.
In the case of multiple base items, this will
return the common root or none if there is no
common root. NOTE: the return type is upcast
to the most general type: SKNode
Query the current view’s subviews for all UISegmentedControls
Query the current view’s subviews for all UIControls
Create an empty query of type UIView
Query the current view’s subviews for all snapshot
instances that are snapshots of the provided type.
e.g. query.snapshots(Button.self) returns query of SnapshotOf
Query the current view’s subviews for all PageControls
Query the current view’s subviews for all DatePickers
Create an empty query of a specific type.
Query the current view’s subviews for all snapshots.
Create a query that contains all siblings of the base item
that match a provided type.
See also convenience versions for general types.
This method returns siblings
of the base items.
To include base items (e.g. self) in siblings use .inclusive option.
This method removes duplicates and is always non-recursive.
This respects parent guides by default.
Query the current item for all sub-items using a non-string identifier.
This is the PREFERRED use of identifiable queries.
See also IdentifiableItem for more information.
Query the current view’s subviews for all Sliders
Query the current item for all sub-items using multiple string identifiers.
Query the current view’s subviews for UIImageViews
Query for the remainder of a defined area with
string identifier and remainder type.
Example: query.remainder(Guide.self, id:“header”)
returns RemainderGuide with header id.
Return a query of the containing SwiftUI hierarchy view
if the current item(s) exist within a SwiftUI hierarchy.
Query for all Shapes or derivitives of shapes
within the current query scope.
Create a query that contains all ancestors from the
base item in ascending order (base –> root) that
match a provided type.
See also convenience versions for general types.
This respects parent guides if they exist, however
with more complex hierarchies (e.g. guide -> view -> guide
searching for the ancestor guide) specify “hybridHierarchy”
to ensure the search will traverse the hierarchy correctly.
In simple cases (e.g. view -> layer, or guide -> layer)
it’s not necessary to specify this.
Query the current view’s subviews for all UILabels
Query the current item for all sub-items of type and ordinal
that exists in an array of integer ordinals.
Query the current view’s, layer’s or guide’s sublayers
for all layers. This includes C3 Layer and CALayers that
conform to OkayType such as TextLayer, etc.
To include all layers (including those that are not
OkayTypes), use “caLayers”.
Query the current item for all sub-items of type and ordinal
that exists in a range of integer ordinals.
Query the current item’s sub items for views with
a UIView integer tag within the set of provided tags.
This will return all views that have one of these tags.
Query the current layer for it’s ancestor layers
up to the root layer. In the case of multiple base
items this will return all ancestor layers with
duplicates removed. NOTE: the return type is always
upcast to the most general type: CALayer.
To get only your prefered type, use select().
Example: layer.query.ancestors.select(Layer.self)
Query the current layer for it’s parent layer.
In the case of multiple base items, this will
return the common parent. NOTE: the return type
is upcast to the most general type: CALayer.
If the parent is a guide then this will return
an empty query. To get the parent guide call
.parent(Guide.self). To get the actual super
layer, use “literalParent”.
For non-view based queries (layers, guides, nodes)
get the containing view(s), of a specified type.
Query the current view’s subviews for all TextViews
Query the current view’s or guide’s subviews for all padder views.
Query for all Shapes of a specific sub-type
and identifier within the current query scope.
See also “composedShapes(id)” operator to query
for composed shapes.
Query the current view’s subviews for all UIButtons
For non-view based queries (layers, guides, nodes) get
all ancestor views from the base item in ascending order.
Query the current view, layer or guide’s sublayers for
all layers that are backing layers of views.
If querying from a view, use .inclusive option to include
the view’s own backing layer.
Query the current guide for it’s parent guide.
In the case of multiple base items, this will
return the common parent. NOTE: the return type
is upcast to the most general type: Guide.
If the parent is a guide, this will return a query
with that guide. If the parent is it’s owning view
(not another guide) then this will return an empty
query because it is restricted to guides. To get
the owning view call “literalParent(View.self)”
(“parent(View.self)” will also work if the guide
does not already have an intermediary parent guide.)
To get an existing super guide regardless you can
also use “literalParent”.
For non-view based queries (layers, guides, nodes) get
all ancestor views from the base item in ascending order
that match a provided type.
Query the current view for it’s ancestor views
up to the root view. In the case of multiple base
items this will return all ancestor views with
duplicates removed. NOTE: the return type is always
upcast to the most general type: UIView.
To get only your prefered type, use select().
Example: view.query.ancestors.select(View.self)
Query for all Shapes of a specific sub-type
and identifier within the current query scope.
See also “composedShapes(id)” operator to query
for composed shapes.
Query the current view’s subviews for all UITextViews
Query the current view for it’s parent view.
In the case of multiple base items, this will
return the common parent. NOTE: the return type
is upcast to the most general type: UIView.
BEWARE: this ignores parent guides. See also,
“parent” operator which respects parent guides.
Query for Grid with string identifier
Query for all composed Shapes with identifier
within the current query scope.
The protocol composition that views, layers, guides and nodes
conform to on all generic wrappers, such as Query, Mutator and others.
Return the current factory if a condition evaluates to true.
Query the current view’s subviews for all StackViews
Query the current item for all sub-items of type and ordinal.
Query the current node’s sibling nodes.
The returned type is upcast to SKNode.
To get only your prefered type, use select().
Example: node.query.siblings.select(Node.self)
To include the current item in the results use
the factory option .inclusive.
Query the current item for all sub-items using multiple non-string tags.
Defaults to matching
of the tags provided, with the option
to specify if
tags must match.
Query for the remainder of a defined area with
optional identifier (or AreaSpec) and remainder type.
Example: query.remainder(Guide.self, for:MyLayout.header)
returns RemainderGuide with header id.
Query the current view’s subviews for all TableViews
Return a query of the containing HostingView
if the current item(s) exist within a SwiftUI hierarchy.
Query the current layer’s sibling layers.
The returned type is upcast to CALayer.
To get only your prefered type, use select().
Example: layer.query.siblings.select(ShapeLayer.self)
To include the current item in the results use
the factory option .inclusive.
This respects parent guides.
Query the current view’s or guide’s subguides for all Guides
of a specific type.
Query the current item’s sub items for views with
a UIView integer tag that matches the provided tag.
Query for a defined area type (View, Layer or Guide)
with optional identifier (or AreaSpec).
Example: query.area(Guide.self, MyLayout.header)
Query for all Shapes of a specific sub-type
within the current query scope.
See also “composedShapes” operator to query
for composed shapes.
Query the current node for it’s parent node.
In the case of multiple base items, this will
return the common parent. NOTE: the return type
is upcast to the most general type: SKNode.
Query the current view’s subviews for all Labels
Query the current view’s subviews for all UITableViews
Return a query of the containing ContextView
if the current item(s) exist within a ContextView.
Query the current view’s subviews for all UISteppers
Query the current view’s subviews for all TextFields
Query the current view’s sibling views.
The returned type is upcast to UIView.
To get only your prefered type, use select().
Example: view.query.siblings.select(Button.self)
To include the current item in the results use
the factory option .inclusive.
This respects parent guides.
Query the current view’s subviews for all SegmentedControls
Query the current item(s) for all sub-items matching:
(a) “identifier”s from a query of items OR
(b) closure derived identifier using “defaultIdentifier”s from a query of items.
Examples:
(a) query.identifiable(Guide.self, using:circles) // using circles’ identifiers
(b) query.identifiable(Guide.self, using:circles) {
// using default identifier (derived from circle)
return MyId.guide(uid:$0).id
Get BackgroundViews that are the background to some parent type
(with identifier), within the current scope.
Query for all composed Shapes with identifier
within the current query scope.
Query the current item for all sub-items using multiple string tags.
Defaults to matching
of the tags provided, with the option
to specify if
tags must match.
Query the current view’s or guide’s subviews for
all views of specified type.
Query the current view’s subviews for all UIPageControls
Query the current layer for it’s root layer.
In the case of multiple base items, this will
return the common root or none if there is no
common root. NOTE: the return type is upcast
to the most general type: CALayer
Query the current view’s subviews for all UIStackViews
Query the current view’s subviews for all UIDatePickers
Query the current guide for it’s ancestor guides
up to the root guide. In the case of multiple base
items this will return all ancestor guides with
duplicates removed. NOTE: the return type is always
upcast to the most general type: Guide.
To get only your prefered type, use select().
Example: guide.query.ancestors.select(AxisGuide.self)
Query the current view’s subviews for all Buttons
Query the current view’s subviews for all Switches
Query the current view’s subviews for all ContentViews
Get ControlBackgroundViews (backgrounds that are control state
dependents) within the current scope.
Query the current view’s subviews for all UIViews.
This is equivalent to traversing UIView.subviews.
NOTE: To include only C3 views or views that conform
to OkayType, use the “views” operator.
Query the current item’s sublayers for all ContentLayers
Query the current view’s or node’s subnodes for all SKNodes
Query the current view’s subviews for all UISliders
Create a query where the result is the parent of the
current base item. In the case of multiple base items
this will return the common parent of those.
See also convenience versions of parent that return
the parent of the most general type (e.g. UIView, CALayer, etc).
Respects parent guides. For example: if base item is
a view within a guide, passing Guide.self will get the
parent guide. However, if UIView.self is specified here,
then the result will be empty because the actual parent
is a guide, not a view. In this example (i.e. passing UIView.self
on a view that is within a guide) use “literalParent” instead
to get actual super view.
Query the current view’s or guide’s subviews for
all views. This includes C3 View and UIViews that
conform to OkayType such as Label, etc.
To include all views (including those that are not
OkayTypes), use “uiViews”.
Query the current view’s, layer’s or guide’s sublayers for
all padder layers.
Branch the factory into a closure to allow more complex
factory conditions, taking the expected item (T) type
needed for the resulting Query.
Get BackgroundViews that are the background to some parent type
(with optional string id), within the current scope.
Create a query where the result is the super item of the
current base item. In the case of multiple base items
this will return the common super item of those.
See also convenience versions of literalParent that return
the super item of the most general type (e.g. UIView,
CALayer, etc). BEWARE: this ignores parent guides. See also,
“parent” operator which respects parent guides.
Query for a defined area type (View, Layer or Guide)
with string identifier.
Example: query.area(Guide.self, id:“page”)
Query the hierarchy for an item of specified type (or max
number of items as specified when creating this query factory)
that matches the provided style selector.
Optionally specify to search ancestors or siblings.
Query the hierarchy for item(s) of specified type (or max
number of items as specified when creating this query factory)
that matches the provided predicate.
Optionally specify to search ancestors or siblings.
Create a query that is the root item of the hierarchy.
This could be the UIWindow for views, UIWindowLayer for
layers and SKScene for nodes.
See also convenience versions for general types.
This respects parent guides if they exist, however
with more complex hierarchies (e.g. guide -> view -> guide
searching for the root guide) specify “hybridHierarchy”
to ensure the search will traverse the hierarchy correctly.
In simple cases (e.g. view -> layer, or guide -> layer)
it’s not necessary to specify this.
Get ControlBackgrounds (backgrounds that are control state
dependents) within the current scope.
Query the current item for all sub-items using a string tag.
This method returns
items with that tag (i.e. not just
the first).
Caveat: a string tag doesn’t necessarily map to a TaggableItem
enum label (where that has been used), since those have a prefix.
e.g. “login” != “com.tags.blahblah.login”
Get Backgrounds that are the background to some parent type
(with optional string id), within the current scope.
Query the current view for it’s root view.
In the case of multiple base items, this will
return the common root or none if there is no
common root. NOTE: the return type is upcast
to the most general type: UIView
Query the current layer’s sublayers for all CALayers.
This is equivalent to traversing CALayer.sublayers.
NOTE: To include only C3 layers or layers that conform
to OkayType, use the “layers” operator.
NOTE: “View” types use “Layer” as their backing layer.
Query the current view’s or node’s subnodes for all SKNodes
of a specific type.
Query for all composed Shapes within the
current query scope.
Query the current item for all sub-items using a non-string tag.
Get Backgrounds that are the background to some parent type
(with identifier), within the current scope.
Query the current view’s or guide’s subguides for all Guides
or custom subtypes of Guide.
For non-view based queries (layers, guides, nodes)
get the containing view(s).
Query current view/guide’s subguides for all grids
Query for a Quadrant with GridSpec identifier
e.g. query.quadrant(MyGrid.header)
or any identifier, or no identifier for all Quadrants.
Query the current view’s subviews for all UITextFields
Query the current view’s, layer’s or guide’s sublayers for
all padder layers that have contained layers of a specific type.
e.g. layer.query.layerPadders(of:CAShapeLayer.self)
Create an empty query of type CALayer
Query the current guide’s sibling guides.
The returned type is upcast to Guide.
To get only your prefered type, use select().
Example: guide.query.siblings.select(AxisGuide.self)
To include the current item in the results use
the factory option .inclusive.
This respects parent guides.
Query the current view’s subviews for all UIImageViews
of a specific type.
Query the current item’s sub-items for items of
the same type (or subtype) of the current item.
Query the current view’s subviews for all UIScrollViews
NOTE: this will return anything that is a subclass of
UIScrollView (e.g. UITextView, UITableView and UICollectionView)
Get Backgrounds within the current scope
Query the current layer for it’s parent layer.
In the case of multiple base items, this will
return the common parent. NOTE: the return type
is upcast to the most general type: Guide.
If the parent is a guide, this will return a guide.
If the parent is an owning view, this will return
an empty query because the “literal” parent of
a guide would be a Guide. This corresponds with
views and layers super items.
Query the current item for all sub-items using multiple non-string identifiers.
Query the current view’s, layer’s or guide’s sublayers
for all layers of a specific type.
Get BackgroundViews within the current scope
Query the current view’s, layer’s or guide’s sublayers
for all layers excluding descendent backing layers.
For example, starting from a view, the “exclusive” layers
would include all of the view’s sublayers (recursively)
while excluding any layers which are backing layers
(or sublayers) of descendent views.
This supports working with sublayers of a specific view
without touching other view’s layers.
(This is a non-standard way of working with layer
hierarchies but occasionally useful.)
Query the current view’s subviews for all ScrollViews
Query for Grid with optional identifier
Query the current view’s subviews for all Labels
of a specific type.
Query the current view’s subviews for all activity indicators
Return a query of any sibling snapshots.
Query using the current (base) item only.
This operator takes the original item and
turns it into the query result.
See also “only” on any Queryable item.
Query current view/guide’s subguides for all quadrants of grids.
Query the current view’s subviews for all Labels
of a specific type.
Query the current node for it’s ancestor nodes
up to the root node. In the case of multiple base
items this will return all ancestor nodes with
duplicates removed. NOTE: the return type is always
upcast to the most general type: SKNode.
To get only your prefered type, use select().
Example: node.query.ancestors.select(SK3DNode.self)
Query the current view’s subviews for ImageViews
Override the max matches of this query.
Return a query from a factory if a provided condition is true
otherwise return a different query from the factory.
The
condition is required, and must match the type
of the
condition.
Query the current view’s subviews for all UISwitches
Query the current view’s subviews for all activity indicators
Add to (union) the options of the current factory
or if specifying
remove those options.
